facts.text: Lands in suit are patel ki huq inam lands in village Nawabag, jagir village of Ellichpur taluq of Berar, comprised in six survey numbers.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts which have given rise to the appeal may number be shortly stated. The lands in suit were companyprised in six survey numbers stated

facts.text: Four Patel families in village: Dongre, Rokade, Raut, Ingle, holding office in rotation of ten years each.

anchor.surface_text: In that village there were four families of Patels some members of which held the Patels office in rotation of ten years each. These four families went

facts.text: Shivajirao of Rokade family died in 1886, had sons Amrit and Bhagwantrao (appellant); Vishwasrao (resp No.1) son of Amrit; Amrit died 1920.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned with the Rokade family. One Shivajirao of that family had two sons, called Amrit and Bhagwant. Bhagwant, as we know, is the appellant

facts.text: Partition in 1923 between appellant Bhagwantrao and respondent No.1 Vishwasrao; appellant claims patelki lands allotted to his share.

anchor.surface_text: In 1923 there was a partition between the appellant and respondent No. 1. The case of the appellant was that as a result of this partition, the patelki

facts.text: Shivajirao, Amritrao, and Vishwasrao worked as Patel.

anchor.surface_text: When Shivajirao was alive, he worked as patel so did Amritrao in his turn. Lastly, Vishwasrao also worked as patel.

facts.text: In 1935, special officer appointed by Government to prepare record of rights for Nawabag; led to holding that appellant not entitled to lands, resume and regrant to working patel (Vishwasrao).

facts.text: Appellant appealed; Commissioner of Berar set aside eviction order but maintained status quo pending final government orders.

facts.text: On December 19, 1941, Financial Commissioner restored Deputy Commissioner's order, holding working patel entitled to full emoluments.

facts.text: Berar ceded by Nizam of Hyderabad in 1853; Inam Rules 1859 promulgated.

facts.text: Inam entry Ex. P-1 dated August 31, 1866: jagir of Nawabag granted by Kings of Delhi to Shah Abdul Huq, confirmed by Nizam 1757; 262 bighas patelki out of 1846.

issues.text: Whether the revenue authorities of the State Government have the right to resume patel ki huq inam lands

anchor.surface_text: It raises some important questions as to the right of the revenue authorities of the State Government concerned, to resume certain lands which are known as patel ki huq inam lands situate in what was previously known as the ceded area of Berar.

issues.text: What is the true nature of the patelki inam lands: do they constitute a grant by way of remuneration or emoluments of the patel's office by the use of the lands, or a grant of land to the patelki family burdened with service making them joint family lands subject to partition?

holdings.text: The patelki inam lands constitute a grant by way of remuneration or emoluments of the patel's office by the use of the lands, not a grant of land to the patelki family burdened with service.

anchor.surface_text: the principal question which falls for decision in this appeal, is the true nature of these patelki inam lands do they constitute a grant by way of remuneration or emoluments of the patels office by the use of the lands, as found by the High Court, or do they constitute a grant of land to the patelki family burdened with service and so long as the service is performed by any member of the family, the lands are joint family lands subject to partition etc.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear evidence from kararnama 1771, inam entry 1866, statements by parties in revenue proceedings confirm grant as emoluments in lieu of service from year to year; rejects partitionable land burdened with service.

holdings.text: Revenue authorities have the right to resume patelki inam lands and regrant to the working patel.

anchor.surface_text: It raises some important questions as to the right of the revenue authorities of the State Government concerned, to resume certain lands which are known as patel ki huq inam lands situate in what was previously known as the ceded area of Berar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supported by Patels and Patwaris Law 1900 ss.3,9,10,11,20 and Berar Land Revenue Code s.190 authorizing resumption of service emoluments to current holder; consistent revenue practice.

holdings.text: The patelki inam was a grant by sovereign authority (confirmed by Nazim), independent of jagir; Inam Rules 1859 and Patels and Patwaris Law 1900 apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Kararnama 1771 shows Nazim (sovereign rep) granted per old usage; overwhelming revenue evidence 1904-1922 treats patelki as watan independent of jagir.

holdings.text: Appellant has no hereditary right to share in patelki inam lands under Inam Rules or Patels Law.

anchor.surface_text: thirdly, even if the aforesaid Rules and provisions applied, the appellant still retained his hereditary rights in the lands

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inam Rule VI(2) inapplicable as service not discontinued; Rule VIII,XI,XIV prohibit shares/alienation; Patels Law s.9 emoluments solely to holder; s.20 bars claims to shares.

holdings.text: Government orders of August 28, 1922 excluded patelki lands as service grant of Amrit; did not deprive rights or preclude later resumption under s.190.

anchor.surface_text: fourthly, the orders of Government dated August 28, 1922, did not confer any new right nor did they deprive anybody of any subsisting right in respect of the patelki inam lands and Government had no right to resume

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1922 order treated lands as homogeneous service unit excluded from jagir resumption; govt retains resumption power for non-performance under Berar Code.

holdings.text: Survey nos. 2/1A and 9/1A did not cease to be patelki inam lands; treated as part of Amrit's homogeneous service grant per 1922 order.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant was that these two plots ceased to be inam lands, when they fell in the resumed portion of the Jagir they were sold by Bannobi

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entire patelki holdings of Amrit excluded as unit in 1922 despite some khalsa; decrees related to other property.

holdings.text: No title by adverse possession to patelki inam lands against Government.

anchor.surface_text: The claim of title by adverse possession can be disposed of in a few words. Once it is held that the lands were given by way of emoluments for the patels office, no question of title by adverse possession arises against Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Service emoluments lands not subject to adverse possession against govt; possession permissive.

holdings.text: Patelki inam is a watan independent of the jagir.

anchor.surface_text: The Patel family has had watandari rights for certainly 150 years or so. I am of opinion therefore that the watan seems independent of the Jagir.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overwhelming evidence from revenue orders 1906-1922 confirms independence; appointments by revenue authorities, not jagirdars.

holdings.text: Civil courts have no jurisdiction over claims to patel emoluments; barred by Patels Law s.20 and Berar Code s.192.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 20 the jurisdiction of the Civil Court is barred with respect to any claim by any person to any emolument appertaining to the office of patel. These provisions clearly indicate that the patelki inam lands are subject to orders passed by the revenue authorities

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit statutory bars on civil jurisdiction for service emoluments claims; matters for revenue authorities.

precedents.citation: Venkata Jagannadha v. Veerabadrayya  1  1921  L.R. 48 I.A. 244.

anchor.surface_text: He has submitted that the High Court has relied on the decision of the Privy Council in Venkata Jagannadha v. Veerabadrayya  1  where the question was whether the karnam service lands enfranchised to a karnam, a village accountant in Madras State, were subject to any claim of partition by other members of the family, and his companyment is that the patelki inam lands in Berar stand on a footing different from karnam service lands in Madras and there are decisions in which it has been held that companysharers have a right to a share in service grants in Berar.

precedents.cited_proposition: karnam service lands enfranchised to a karnam were not subject to partition by family members

precedents.citation: Krishnarao v. Nilkantha and Others  2  A.I.R.  1922  Nag. 52.

anchor.surface_text: The first decision to which oar attention has been drawn is Krishnarao v. Nilkantha and Others  2 . That was a case of a jagir, and it was held that it came under the third class, and numberhing regarding ordinary rule is that if persons are entitled beneficially to shares in an estate, they may have a partition. It was further held that property companysisting of an ordinary inam village was liable to partition at the suit of a companysharer except when it was held on a saranjam or other impartible tenure or where the terms of the grant impose a companydition upon its enjoyment.

precedents.cited_proposition: ordinary inam village liable to partition unless impartible or conditional

precedents.citation: Mir Subhan Ali v. Imami Begum  3  A.I.R.  1931  P.C. 157.

anchor.surface_text: The next decision is that of the Privy Council in Mir Subhan Ali v. Imami Begum  3  all that was laid down there was that the devolution and incidents of an inam estate in Berar were regulated by the Inam Rules, 1859, but only in matters number mentioned in the sanad or certificate or other document evidencing the special terms of the grant in the particular case.

precedents.case_name: Mir Subhan Ali v. Imami Begum
precedents.cited_proposition: devolution of inam estate in Berar regulated by Inam Rules 1859 unless special terms in grant document

precedents.citation: Lakhamgouda Basavaprabhu Sardesai v. Baswantrao and Others  4

anchor.surface_text: In Lakhamgouda Basavaprabhu Sardesai v. Baswantrao and Others  4  the Privy Council pointed out the distinction between the grant of an office to be remunerated by the use of land and the grant of land burdened with service it said that in the former case, the land would be prima facie resumable but number so in the latter case, unless the terms of the grant or the circumstances in which it was made established that it was resumable.

precedents.case_name: Lakhamgouda Basavaprabhu Sardesai v. Baswantrao and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between grant of office remunerated by land use (resumable) and grant of land burdened with service (not resumable unless terms say so)
precedents.cited_holding: in the former case, the land would be prima facie resumable but number so in the latter case

precedents.citation: Jaiwantrao and Another v. Sahebrao  1   1933  29 Nag. L.R. 210.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Jaiwantrao and Another v. Sahebrao  1 , the inam certificate issued to the head of the senior branch of a family of Deshmukh watandars stated that the village was granted for personal maintenance to the claimant, his descendants and companysharers Accordingly, it was held that a companysharer was entitled to possession of his share appearing from the inam statement.

precedents.cited_proposition: where inam certificate specifies grant to claimant, descendants and co-sharers, co-sharer entitled to share

precedents.citation: Raje Shrinivasrao v. Raje Vinayakrao 2  I.L.R.  1949  Nag. 1.

anchor.surface_text: In Raje Shrinivasrao v. Raje Vinayakrao 2  there was grant of two villages to the great- grandfather of the appellant and the respondent, who were brothers, and his lineal heirs or his successors . The question was whether primogeniture was to be the order of descent or the estate was impartible. It was held that the ordinary principles of Hindu Law were applicable and the earlier decision in Mir Subhan Ali v. Imami Begam  3  was referred to.

precedents.cited_proposition: ordinary Hindu law principles apply to descent unless specified otherwise

anchor.surface_text: the principal question which falls for decision in this appeal, is the true nature of these patelki inam lands do they constitute a grant by way of remuneration or emoluments of the patels office by the use of the lands, as found by the High Court, or do they constitute a grant of land to the patelki family burdened with service and so long as the service is performed by any member of the family, the lands are joint family lands subject to partition etc.
